fields.headline: Michael Holden's All ears
fields.bodyText: Waiting for a train to leave I saw one of those everyday acts of domestic heroism unfold along the carriage as a woman wrangled her three kids on board – boys aged between 10 and 16 – with the hard-fought nonchalance of John Wayne driving steers across Texas. Boy 1 (running full pelt down the aisle toward a pair of seats with a table and throwing himself down) "Here! Here!" Boy 2 (joining him seconds later, then reaching an uncomfortable conclusion) "It's wet." Boy 1 "So's this one." Boy 2 (not to be outdone) "This one's wetter." Boys 1 & 2 (prepared to overlook their discomfort when it became apparent their mother and brother might take seats across the aisle) "Can we sit here?" Mother "Yeah" Boys 1& 2 "Thanks" Mother (settling in, then realising that the two other kids were able to exploit a blind spot in her vision) "Get over here." Boys 1 & 2 "But …" Mother "Now!" Boy 1 (having trapped his brother in the window seat) "If you need to go to the toilet I ain't moving. [Pausing for thought] Where is the toilet?" Boy 2 (instigating an exchange of dead arms) "You should have gone." Boy 3 (staring at a DVD case of the movie Speed, as though it might somehow begin to play on its own.) "Mum, how do you do this?" Boy 1 "Stupid kid." Boy 3 "I'm not a kid I'm an adult." Mum (with authority that seemed to admonish the entire train) "ENOUGH!" The boys just stared each other out, wondering who would make the next move.
